definition: decorum/propriety/arrangement or form (of piece of writing)
body/form/style/system/substance/to experience/aspect (linguistics)
to gather/to unite/to unify/whole
What a scandal!/Whatever next?
not according with decorum (idiom); scandalous/bad form/unacceptable behavior
not according with decorum/scandalous/bad form/unacceptable behavior
lacking in propriety/bad form

sentences.english: Short trousers are not proper at a dance.
sentences.chinese: 舞會上穿短褲不成體統。

sentences.english: He did not look at the woman as he spoke. It would not have been seemly .
sentences.chinese: 他說話的時候，沒有去看女人，因爲那是不成體統的。

sentences.english: The problem with Establishment Republicans is they abhor the unseemliness of a political brawl.
sentences.chinese: 共和黨的人問題是他們厭惡不成體統的政治上的爭鬥。

sentences.english: My handwriting has gone down with using the computer so much.
sentences.chinese: 用電腦太多，我的字寫得不成體統了。

sentences.english: Short trousers are improper at a dance.
sentences.chinese: 舞會上穿短褲不成體統。

sentences.english: It's considered improper to be unclothed in public.
sentences.chinese: 在公共場合赤身裸體被認爲是不成體統的。

sentences.english: It wasn't quite the done thing for women to drink in pubs in those days.
sentences.chinese: 那年月女的到酒店喝酒可不成體統。

sentences.english: She behaved very badly at the party.
sentences.chinese: 她在聚會上的舉止真不成體統。

sentences.english: This sort of thing simply isn't done.
In the past it was considered indecent for a lady to ride a horse astride.
sentences.chinese: 過去認爲淑女跨騎馬是件有失體統的事。

definition: to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
to display one's slight skill before an expert (idiom)
to whisper to one another's ear
chicken-hearted (idiom)/gutless
lit. not even the chickens and dogs are left undisturbed (idiom)/fig. great commotion/pandemonium
lit. view a text and interpret (idiom); to interpret word by word without understanding the meaning/a far-fetched interpretation
to take revenge and wipe out a grudge (idiom)
to upbraid
old school/conservative faction
to use public office to avenge private wrongs
to be a thief
to boast shamelessly/to talk big
to return good for evil (idiom)/to requite evil with good
a golden house to keep one's mistress (idiom); a magnificent house built for a beloved woman
to obstruct/to impede
hard to fathom a person's mind (idiom)
